Part A: Describe the treatment enslaved people experienced aboard ships such as those referenced in the source.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • Aboard slave ships, Africans suffered violence such as beatings and torture at the hands of the crew.

  • Aboard slave ships Africans were crowded in unsanitary conditions.

  • Africans suffered from malnourishment aboard slave ships.

Part B: Describe a broader historical context of ibn Seid’s autobiography that is not specifically addressed in the source.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • Forty-eight percent of all Africans who were brought to the United States landed in Charleston, South Carolina, the center of United States slave trading.

  • Trans-Saharan commerce introduced Islam to West Africa, a region from which many people were taken captive and enslaved.

  • Profits from growing crops such as sugar in the Americas motivated the slave trade.

  • South Carolina was dominated by the slave-cotton system, in which enslaved African Americans were especially valuable as commodities because of the demand for enslaved laborers.

The response accomplishes the task set by part B of the question.

Part C: Explain how slave narratives help further understanding in the field of African American Studies.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • Many slave narratives provide details from formerly enslaved people in Africa; this provides evidence that Africa was not a place with an undocumented or unknowable history.

  • Slave narratives are an example of how African American Studies scholars utilize literature to develop an understanding of the African diaspora.

  • By studying the historical and literary elements of slave narratives, African American Studies scholars can use an interdisciplinary approach to understanding the past.

  • Scholars examine slave narratives as political texts to understand the factors that contributed to the end of slavery and the slave trade.

  • Slave narratives provide a variety of accounts of enslaved people which demonstrates the diverse backgrounds and experiences of Africans.

The response accomplishes the task set by part C of the question.

Part D: Explain how the transatlantic slave trade destabilized West African societies.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • The slave trade increased regional conflicts by providing profit incentives to increase the enslavement of members of neighboring societies.

  • Domestic wars between kingdoms were made worse by the prevalence of firearms received from trade with Europeans during the transatlantic slave trade.

  • To maintain local dominance and grow their wealth, African leaders sold soldiers and war captives from opposing ethnic groups. This practice increased regional conflict.

  • The slave trade caused long-term instability through the loss of kin who would have raised families and passed on traditions.

The response accomplishes the task set by part D of the question.
